App description:
Enter the world of Cirque du Soleil for an up, close and intimate look at some of their most iconic shows. Swing into a Mexican daydream in THROUGH THE MASKS OF LUZIA, or dive into a hypnotic underwater universe in DREAMS OF O.  Challenge your perceptions in INSIDE THE BOX OF KURIOS and watch an epic battle unfold in the mythical world of K - THE BATTLE WITHIN. Cirque du Soleil VR brings these stunning experiences to life like never before.

NEW EXPERIENCE - ALEGRA - A SPARK OF LIGHT is an incredible re-imagining of one of Cirque du Soleils most iconic productions. Alegra - A Spark of Light; a universal tale of change, renewal and enlightenment.

derrick33333Jul 4 at 1:29 PM
Great for New Cirque Folks

What I liked:
- Great content - it puts you right at the center of the show at Cirque. Each video is ~10-13 minutes long, but only has one main act, and a small side act. It is like a teaser for each Cirque show that pulls you in for more. One hour of decent Cirque content pulls you into the show, making you want to watch the rest of it.
- Short and sweet - 10-13 minutes each; one main/one side act. No fluff, no audience, and great visuals.
- Decent price at $8. Quite honestly, it feels like a major "promo" for Cirque, so it should be free if they really want to pull people in as a marketing tool.

Cons:
- The show makes you feel bad for the actors, who were all fired due to covid19 and the company filed bankruptcy, putting them all out of a job. The VR shows you how difficult most of their acts are, and how high risk they are at death if anything goes wrong. It paints a very poor picture for the billionaire owner of Cirque who fired everybody to bankrupt the company, while hoarding his billions.
- While the content is great, it is just a stream of content from Cirque, advertising each show to draw you in to pay to watch the rest of them. I think they should have given this away for free as a marketing ploy, although I do understand that there are costs.

Overall, for $8, it's not a lot, and the content is good. It just makes you bitter at the founder of Cirque who screwed all these hardworking people out of a job, who risk their lives to show a good act.

Artifacts, weird angles & slow-motion

This is obviously my subjective opinion; While some of the angles and post effects work to "tell the story" some other takes you out from it completely.

(Spoilers ahead)

1. O - this was just artifact fest, as everything is really dark and video compression doesn't like dark colors you can see all the pixels dancing around more than the actual acrobats.

2. Alegra - The scene with the hula acrobat has some weird bloom effect that takes you completely out of the experience... The slowing down to getting still effect works for the story's sake, but that bloom is just ugh... Awful. Later on, having the rope acrobats filmed and displayed upside down is mind boggling (not in a good way) it just messes with your head and you're trying to understand what you're watching.

3. Luzia - While the filming angles work here (and the fast motion to slow motion kinda does too) the contortionist act while great, was not filmed at the better angle, I know that was on purpose but it didn't work for me. At the credits scene, there's this guy juggling awesomely, but you guys sped up his footage, which doesn't make any sense because his ability cannot be appreciated that way.

-------

I understand why this has a cost, and I am satisfied with how much I paid for what I got. I just couldn't help but think "this will be the VHS aesthetic of the future, with weird angles, compression artifacts"

Sorry to be this harsh but I want future Felix and Paul experiences to be as great as they can be.
